DataElement.preferredName: Medullary Thyroid Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Stage group determined from information on the tumor (T), regional node (N) and metastases (M) and by grouping cases with similar prognosis for medullary cancer for all age groups.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma Stage Grouping
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from the C-cells of the thyroid gland.  It is closely associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes.  Approximately 10% to 20% of medullary thyroid carcinomas are familial.  Patients usually present with a thyroid nodule that is painless and firm.  In the majority of cases nodal involvement is present at diagnosis.  Surgery is the preferred treatment for both primary lesions and recurrences.  This carcinoma is generally not very sensitive to radiation and almost unresponsive to chemotherapy.  - 2002_An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from the C-cells of the thyroid gland.  It is closely associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes.  Approximately 10% to 20% of medullary thyroid carcinomas are familial.  Patients usually present with a thyroid nodule that is painless and firm.  In the majority of cases nodal involvement is present at diagnosis.  Surgery is the preferred treatment for both primary lesions and recurrences.  This carcinoma is generally not very sensitive to radiation and almost unresponsive to chemotherapy.  - 2002

Concepts.definition: A neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from the C-cells of the thyroid gland. It is closely associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes. Approximately 10% to 20% of medullary thyroid carcinomas are familial. Patients usually present with a thyroid nodule that is painless and firm. In the majority of cases nodal involvement is present at diagnosis. Surgery is the preferred treatment for both primary lesions and recurrences. This carcinoma is generally not very sensitive to radiation and almost unresponsive to chemotherapy.

Property.preferredDefinition: Stage Grouping; an assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage. (caDSR)

Concepts.definition: An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. mc 5/17/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from the C-cells of the thyroid gland.  It is closely associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes.  Approximately 10% to 20% of medullary thyroid carcinomas are familial.  Patients usually present with a thyroid nodule that is painless and firm.  In the majority of cases nodal involvement is present at diagnosis.  Surgery is the preferred treatment for both primary lesions and recurrences.  This carcinoma is generally not very sensitive to radiation and almost unresponsive to chemotherapy.  - 2002_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding indicating that the extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

Concepts.definition: The extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage I Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage I Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage I includes: T1, N0, M0.  T1: Tumor size 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage I Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage I includes: T1, N0, M0.  T1: Tumor size 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage II Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage II Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage II includes: (T2, N0, M0); (T3, N0, M0).  T2: Tumor more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T3: Tumor more than 4 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the thyroid gland, or tumor of any size with minimal extrathyroid extension (e.g., extension to sternothyroid muscle or perithyroid soft tissues).  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage II Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage II includes: (T2, N0, M0); (T3, N0, M0).  T2: Tumor more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T3: Tumor more than 4 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the thyroid gland, or tumor of any size with minimal extrathyroid extension (e.g., extension to sternothyroid muscle or perithyroid soft tissues).  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage III Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage III Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage III includes: (T1, N1a, M0); (T2, N1a, M0); (T3, N1a, M0). T1: Tumor size 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T2: Tumor more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T3: Tumor more than 4 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the thyroid gland, or tumor of any size with minimal extrathyroid extension (e.g., extension to sternothyroid muscle or perithyroid soft tissues).  N1a: Metastasis to pretracheal, paratracheal or prelaryngeal/Delphian lymph nodes (Level VI lymph nodes).  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage III Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage III includes: (T1, N1a, M0); (T2, N1a, M0); (T3, N1a, M0). T1: Tumor size 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T2: Tumor more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T3: Tumor more than 4 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the thyroid gland, or tumor of any size with minimal extrathyroid extension (e.g., extension to sternothyroid muscle or perithyroid soft tissues).  N1a: Metastasis to pretracheal, paratracheal or prelaryngeal/Delphian lymph nodes (Level VI lymph nodes).  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage IVA Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage IVA Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVA includes: (T4a, N0, M0); (T4a, N1a, M0); (T1, N1b, M0); (T2, N1b, M0); (T3, N1b, M0); (T4a, N1b, M0).  T4a: Moderately advanced local disease.  Tumor of any size extending beyond the thyroid gland capsule to invade subcutaneous soft tissues, larynx, trachea, esophagus, or recurrent laryngeal nerve. ).  T1: Tumor size 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T2: Tumor more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T3: Tumor more than 4 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the thyroid gland, or tumor of any size with minimal extrathyroid extension (e.g., extension to sternothyroid muscle or perithyroid soft tissues).  T4b: Very advanced disease.  Tumor invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid artery or mediastinal vessels.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  N1a: Metastasis to pretracheal, paratracheal or prelaryngeal/Delphian lymph nodes (Level VI lymph nodes).  N1b: Metastasis to unilateral, bilateral or contralateral cervical (Levels I, II, III, IV, or V) or retropharyngeal or superior mediastinal lymph nodes (Level VII). M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVA Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVA includes: (T4a, N0, M0); (T4a, N1a, M0); (T1, N1b, M0); (T2, N1b, M0); (T3, N1b, M0); (T4a, N1b, M0).  T4a: Moderately advanced local disease.  Tumor of any size extending beyond the thyroid gland capsule to invade subcutaneous soft tissues, larynx, trachea, esophagus, or recurrent laryngeal nerve.  T1: Tumor size 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T2: Tumor more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the thyroid gland.  T3: Tumor more than 4 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the thyroid gland, or tumor of any size with minimal extrathyroid extension (e.g., extension to sternothyroid muscle or perithyroid soft tissues).  T4b: Very advanced disease.  Tumor invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid artery or mediastinal vessels.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  N1a: Metastasis to pretracheal, paratracheal or prelaryngeal/Delphian lymph nodes (Level VI lymph nodes).  N1b: Metastasis to unilateral, bilateral or contralateral cervical (Levels I, II, III, IV, or V) or retropharyngeal or superior mediastinal lymph nodes (Level VII). M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage IVB Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage IVB Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVB includes: T4b, Any N, M0.  T4b: Very advanced disease.  Tumor invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid artery or mediastinal vessels.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVB Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVB includes: T4b, Any N, M0.  T4b: Very advanced disease.  Tumor invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid artery or mediastinal vessels.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stage IVC Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stage IVC Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVC includes: Any T, Any N, M1.  M1: Distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVC Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVC includes: Any T, Any N, M1.  M1: Distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Thyroid Gland Medullary Carcinoma American Joint Committee on Cancer Stage Grouping Stage
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from the C-cells of the thyroid gland.  It is closely associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes.  Approximately 10% to 20% of medullary thyroid carcinomas are familial.  Patients usually present with a thyroid nodule that is painless and firm.  In the majority of cases nodal involvement is present at diagnosis.  Surgery is the preferred treatment for both primary lesions and recurrences.  This carcinoma is generally not very sensitive to radiation and almost unresponsive to chemotherapy.  - 2002:A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A neuroendocrine carcinoma arising from the C-cells of the thyroid gland. It is closely associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes. Approximately 10% to 20% of medullary thyroid carcinomas are familial. Patients usually present with a thyroid nodule that is painless and firm. In the majority of cases nodal involvement is present at diagnosis. Surgery is the preferred treatment for both primary lesions and recurrences. This carcinoma is generally not very sensitive to radiation and almost unresponsive to chemotherapy.
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
